;1969 年春天，;理查德·尼克松;抵达白宫，他和他的国家安全顾问;亨利·基辛格;，开始策划一场地缘政治地震。中国发生共产主义革命二十年后，北京和华盛顿仍然没有建立正式关系，而尼克松虽然是一名激烈的反共人士，但他希望找到一种方法将占世界人口五分之一的中国人拉入全球体系。周三去世，享年一百岁的基辛格有自己的动机：他后来在《<提供数据》一书中发表的口述历史中回忆道，他打算“让中国与俄罗斯较量”。 -url="https://www.amazon.com/Kissinger-Reflections-Diplomacy-Strategy-Leadership/dp/1250219442" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL" ：“https://www.amazon.com/Kissinger-Reflections-Diplomacy-Strategy-Leadership/dp/1250219442”}" href="https://www.amazon.com/Kissinger-Reflections-Diplomacy-Strategy- Leadership/dp/1250219442" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">;基辛格论基辛格;。” “我们不希望俄罗斯成为共产主义世界的唯一代言人；我们想分开。”

;

;一开始，尼克松和基辛格并不是明显的搭档。 1968 年共和党总统初选期间，基辛格在为竞争对手提供建议时，将鹰派、反复无常的尼克松描述为“所有竞选人中最危险的一个”。但是，在尼克松获得提名后，基辛格的地位和野心让他们走到了一起，基辛格成了知己。在任期间，他们开始执行一项秘密、迂回且高度个人化的使命。前往巴黎，参加;戴高乐;的葬礼1970年，尼克松在爱丽舍宫举行的招待会上发现了中国大使，并敦促基辛格临时采取措施，说：“如果你发现他独自站了一分钟，请走到他身边，告诉他我们想谈谈。 ”但大使并不孤单，这一刻已经过去了。接下来，尼克松和基辛格试图通过波兰进行接触；美国大使以出席南斯拉夫驻华沙大使馆时装秀为借口，突然向中国大使走近。 “他逃跑了，”基辛格回忆道，“我们的大使追上他，并向他提出了这个请求。”

;

;双方同意通过巴基斯坦交换信息。中国的通讯是手写的，由信使从北京传送到伊斯兰堡再到华盛顿特区，然后巴基斯坦大使将它们送到基辛格的办公室。 “我们用没有水印的纸质打印信息进行回复，”他回忆道，这样一旦被发现，他就可以质疑这些信息的真实性。 （基辛格对保密非常狂热，甚至在同事之间也是如此，以至于参谋长联席会议收买了一名职员来监视他的办公室。）

;

;1971 年 7 月，在巴基斯坦军方的帮助下，基辛格制定了一项保密协议。秘密中国之旅。这一突破伴随着可耻的权衡：为了保护他们的访问权，基辛格和尼克松忽视了巴基斯坦军队正在进行宗派屠杀的证据。美国驻达卡外交官阿彻·布拉德在发给华盛顿上级的愤怒电报中将东巴基斯坦（现为孟加拉国）的暴行描述为“选择性种族灭绝”。 （总而言之，据信以穆斯林为主的军队至少杀害了三十万名印度教徒的孟加拉人，并迫使一千万人逃往印度。） 在白宫 ;会议;，基辛格秘密旅行归来后，将其“斗篷和匕首”演习的成功归功于巴基斯坦军事领导人阿加·穆罕默德将军叶海亚·汗 (Yahya Khan) 开玩笑说，“自上次印度教大屠杀以来，叶海亚还没有这么开心过！”

;

;加里·巴斯 (Gary Bass)，普林斯顿大学政治学教授，《;血电报;，”尼克松和基辛格参与这些事件的历史告诉我，“向中国开放是这是一项重大成就，但它给孟加拉人和印度人带来了可怕的代价，这一点也应该被记住。”基辛格的成就所伴随的妥协融合在定义他的遗产的双重性中。

;
;
;

;在动荡的八年里，从 1969 年到 1975 年担任国家安全顾问，并担任国务卿1973年至1977年担任国务卿期间，基辛格进行了一场马拉松式的曲折外交：与苏联缓和关系、将美国从越南撤军、在以色列与阿拉伯邻国之间建立关系。他也是推翻萨尔瓦多·阿连德;萨尔瓦多·阿连德< /a>;，民主选举产生的智利社会党总统，他被指控授权秘密轰炸柬埔寨以铲除越共，违反了国际法。 1973年，当他因促成与北越停火的贡献而被授予诺贝尔和平奖时，诺贝尔委员会的两名成员辞职以示抗议。基辛格拒绝了早些时候的和平主张，成功地安排了美国的退出，但对越南人来说，战斗仍在继续。音乐家汤姆·莱勒 (Tom Lehrer) 有句名言：“当亨利·基辛格获得诺贝尔和平奖时，政治讽刺就变得过时了。”

;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;

;但是《外交事务》前编辑吉迪恩·罗斯将基辛格的服务记录列为仅次于尼克松和杰拉尔德·福特的第二位哈里·杜鲁门、迪恩·艾奇逊和乔治·马歇尔三人组，;建立了战后秩序;，在美国外交的万神殿中。罗斯说：“即使相对于他所做的所有坏事和他做事的坏方式来说，这也是非同寻常的。”很久之后，基辛格的声望激怒了他的批评者，尽管他有时以令人消除戒备的坦率来拥抱自己的声誉。众所周知，他在迎接一位警惕的晚餐伙伴时，开场白是：“我想你就是那些认为我是战犯的人之一。”

;

;;海因茨·阿尔弗雷德·基辛格 (Heinz Alfred Kissinger) 于 1923 年出生于巴伐利亚城市菲尔特，作为正统犹太人长大并受到反犹太主义者的欺凌。 1938 年，纳粹上台后，他的家人搬到了纽约，他也入籍了美国人，不过他后来在第二次世界大战期间返回德国，担任美国陆军第 84 步兵师情报行动的翻译。在战争的最后时刻，他的部队来到了汉诺威附近阿勒姆的一个集中营，他后来称这是“我所经历过的最令人震惊的经历”。 （他的祖母和其他十二个亲戚都死在集中营里了。）他的早年生活在他对权力的敬畏中留下了烙印。前美国大使 Martin Indyk，在 ;关于基辛格在中东的记录;的书，观察到他的最终目标本质上从来就不是和平；这是秩序，是威尔逊唯心主义失败所塑造的生命历程的产物。但是，基辛格对等级制度的信仰使他对弱者的痛苦和权力视而不见，这种模式在当今的中东仍然令人难以忘怀。因迪克称其为“低估了较小区域行为体扰乱超级大国意志的能力。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;战后，基辛格从哈佛大学毕业，在教职中晋升，并进入政界，在尼克松丢脸后留在白宫。与他之前和之后的任何一位外交官不同，他成为媒体的焦点，媒体几十年来一直在追踪他的交易。卸任后，他成为了那些希望进入北京和其他首都的企业领导人的高价顾问。但近年来，他对中国开放的愿景遭到了严厉的重新评估。植根于 1969 年最初的脆弱方针的“接触”政策，无论左翼还是右翼都被视为空洞的讨价还价。它使美国公司受益，但导致美国工人工资停滞不前。中国已经变得强大，但并不自由，而且越来越不信任美国参与亚洲事务。基辛格开始告诉来访者，他担心第一次世界大战重演。 2019 年，在他最初接触半个世纪后，中国和美国在贸易和台湾问题上陷入了激烈的争端，他告诉我，他很担心 ;在当时的一次采访中;表示，这种尖刻的争吵会“让双方都认为对方是另一方”永远的对手。”

;

;尽管他的年龄已经上升到一个世纪，而且他的身高和大理石般的男中音越来越低，但他似乎很喜欢影子政治家的角色。 7月，当他最后一次访问北京时，中国领导人;习近平;称赞他是“老令拜登政府恼火的是，他允许基辛格会见国防部长李尚福，而当时正受到美国制裁的李尚福拒绝会见美国官员。

;

;直到最后，基辛格都意识到有必要将他的遗产账簿推向他喜欢的方向。作为一位多产作家，其荣誉包括 1980 年国家图书奖，其 ;他的回忆录第一卷;，他他从不回避在书评中用不友善的旁白来表达自己的不满。 “亨利的母亲不可能以他认为足够的方式评论他的一本书，”罗斯告诉我。基辛格并非对批评视而不见，但他从未停止过平衡自己记录的谈判。 “基辛格是一位现实主义者，特别是在理解世界本来面目，并以功利主义呼吁少害己害方面。这就是他的天才，”罗斯说。 “批评家只关注不好的事情。基辛格本人只想关注好的事情。” ♦

;从 Merchant Ivory 改编自 EM Forster 小说的经典作品到 BBC 深受喜爱的简·奥斯汀作品《 《傲慢与偏见》最伟大的古装剧是那些成功地向现代观众传达了另一个时代的情感体验的剧。在这一集中的《Critics at Large》中，特约编剧文森·坎宁安 (Vinson Cunningham)、娜奥米·弗莱 (Naomi Fry) 和亚历山德拉·施瓦茨 (Alexandra Schwartz) 讨论了他们个人最喜欢的作品，即格蕾塔·葛韦格 (Greta Gerwig) 对“;小妇人;”和简·坎皮恩的《明亮的星星》，记录了诗人约翰·济慈和范妮·布劳恩之间不幸的爱情故事——以及这种类型正在如何变化。通常，这些故事的乐趣在于它们对过去的风俗习惯的严格描述。但最近的热门剧集，包括《狄金森》 ;、”“布里奇顿”和“;The Great;”采用了明显的非历史主义，这在对话、配乐以及对种族和性的处理中很明显。主持人思考了 Apple TV+ 上的《海盗》如何与伊迪丝·沃顿的小说有所不同，因为它跳过了构成沃顿故事支柱的社会政治细节。当代的繁荣是增强了这一流派的吸引力，还是淡化了它？坎宁安说：“当我们发现过去与我们息息相关时，过去的奇异之处正是让我们感到惊奇的原因。” “如果你让一切都变得相关，那么你就消除了发现的兴奋感。”

;Most of us aren't quite sure how we're supposed to feel about the dramatic improvement of machine capabilities—the class of tools and techniques we've collectively labelled, in shorthand, artificial intelligence.有些人难以抑制自己的兴奋。温和地说，其他人则感到震惊。这两个极端的支持者的共同点是坚信人工智能的崛起将代表人类历史上的彻底中断——我们没有相关背景或比较基础的事件。如果情况很可能如此，那么我们就没有任何准备好接受它的承诺或加强自己以应对最坏的结果。无论出于何种原因，人类中的一小部分人倾向于对崇高事物感到敬畏或恐惧。然而，我们其他人更愿意相信未来将以更加有序和明智的方式到来。我们在某种程度上感到安慰的是，一些新的、据称是独特的事物与旧的、熟悉的事物非常相似。这些解释都是通货紧缩的。他们的目的是让我们不必对明天的问题产生神经质的感觉。 If such hazards can be redescribed as merely updated versions of the problems of today, we are licensed to have ;normal; feelings about them instead.

;

;This isn't to say that these redescriptions invariably make us feel good, but some of them do.当这些论点涉及与特定技术相关的耸人听闻的威胁时，它们尤其令人安心。 In this magazine, ;Daniel Immerwahr recently proposed; that the history of photography ought to make us feel better about the future of deepfakes: the proliferation of photographic imagery was coextensive with the proliferation of such imagery's manipulation, and for the most part we've proved ourselves able to interpret photographic evidence with the proper circumstantial understanding and scrutiny—at least when we feel like it.伊默瓦尔的论点并不是说这里没有什么可看的，而是大部分可看的东西以前都见过，而且至少到目前为止，我们已经设法蒙混过关了。这是一个推论性的主张，因此受到通常的限制。我们不能确定人类社会不会因为这种最先进的诡辩而陷入新的不稳定。但像伊默瓦尔这样的历史学家的作用是为我们提供一个可供粗略比较的参考类，而有了参考类就带来了类似希望的东西。 The likelihood of technological determinism is counterposed with a reasonable, grounded faith that we have our wits about us.

;

;There is another kind of deflationary argument, one more often associated with the broader and more generic threat of machine intelligence rather than with a discrete technology like deepfakes.这里的逻辑前提不是人类精明的先例，而是对人类易犯错误的类比。这或许可以称为“我们什么时候这么伟大了？”方法。 ChatGPT 产生很多废话的幻觉？我们自己的大脑会产生很多无意义的幻觉。 ;Facial recognition; misidentifies criminal suspects?目击者经常会误认犯罪嫌疑人。这些说法有或多或少复杂的版本。这种思维方式的一个缺点是，强调我们自己的蹩脚，再加上方便、懒惰或技术迷恋的原因，可能会成为一个不在场的借口——一个授予机器不劳而获和未经审查的权力的借口。这种态度的不利后果包括失控的反馈循环：低于平均水平的飞行员导致飞机坠毁，我们通过越来越多地依赖自动化系统来弥补，自动化系统为更糟糕的飞行员提供了余地（他们缺乏技能或培训来恢复飞行器，当飞机坠毁时）自动化系统失败）。但总体而言，高深莫测的机器与极端平庸的人类之间的对比再次被认为是令人宽慰的。机器可能会犯错误，但这些错误与我们自己犯的错误并没有本质上的不同。有人可能会补充说，机器需要进行迭代工程。一旦我们放弃非理性偏见，转而支持人类理性——一旦我们意识到我们应该更喜欢偶尔发生可怕事故的自动驾驶汽车，而不是经常发生可怕事故的人类驾驶汽车——我们就会屈服于我们的依赖on these tools in the way that we reconciled ourselves to reliance on the plow.

;

;Both of these modes of consolation—by precedent or by analogy—rest on the assumption that history is continuous, that change is more or less gradual and invisible to those experiencing it, and that humanity will remain in a position to address new complications in the way it has addressed, with varying degrees of success, prior ones.所有这些假设很可能被证明是正确的，并且做出这些假设或发现它们具有说服力并不是没有道理的。它们提供了我们担心我们习惯担心的事情的理由，而不是我们甚至不知道如何担心的事情。 But they ignore, elide, or diminish the possibility, however far-fetched, that we might have to confront a genuine discontinuity.

;

;The crux of the residual case for doom is the ;alignment problem;—the prospect that an artificial superintelligence might have no use for human价值观。 （这些价值观通常没有明确说明，但可能包括生命神圣不可侵犯、人类有尊严等信念。）先进的人工智能甚至不需要充满敌意；冷漠同样是不幸的。你可以给一台先进的机器黑匣子一个明确的指令，然后发现它毫无感情地执行它的目标：你要求一个打扫房间的机器人减少不整洁，它会杀死你的狗。摆脱这种末日担忧的方法之一是确定智力和价值观必然相关，一个具有足够智力的实体必然会吸收我们的道德担忧。然而，在这种情况下，任何通过连续性（通过先例或类比）进行的论证都不可能让我们感觉更好：我们熟悉凶残的反社会者的存在。凶残的反社会者是人工智能安全社区中人们所谓的正交论的一种存在证明——智力和道德存在于不同维度的观点。在过去的几十万年里，我们已经能够在凶残的反社会分子将我们彻底消灭之前遏制住。但是，以凶残的反社会人格者的形式出现的机器超级智能，或者在任何情况下与传统的凶残的反社会人格者结盟，很可能会控制前所未有的资源。这既是真正的坏事，又是真正的新事。这种事关生存的威胁可能看起来极其难以置信或遥远。 But it, by definition, would seem to flout any attempts to provide historical easement.

;

;At first glance, David Runciman's “;The Handover: How We Gave Control of Our Lives to Corporations, States, and AIs;” seems poised to furnish just such a reassurance—to domesticate the alignment problem. Runciman, a witty and refined writer, is a professor of politics at Cambridge and a contributing editor to the ;London Review of Books;, which has also provided a home for his enlivening podcasts.他还是多克斯福德的第四任朗西曼子爵，这个头衔激发了人们对他对历史连续性的承诺的不小的信心。朗西曼的基本论点以逍遥研讨会的优雅而蓬乱的方式展开，即对齐问题实际上并不是异常，即将到来的奇点最好被历史化为第二奇点。朗西曼为我们与另外两个人工机构（国家和公司）关系中的协调问题找到了一个先例和类比。 This idea, in his account, first emerged in 1651, when Thomas Hobbes described ;the Leviathan; as, in Runciman's words, “a kind of robot.”当然，霍布斯并没有称其为机器人（这个术语首次出现在十九世纪二十年代），但他确实阐述了他对国家的愿景：“人造人；机器人”。尽管比自然人拥有更高的地位和力量，但它的目的是为了保护和防御自然人。”正如朗西曼（Runciman）解释这一概念时所说：“我们组装它的方式与构造任何其他运动部件机器相同。这个产品的设计与其创造者相似。但它可以做我们做不到的事情。它比我们强大得多。这就是我们最初建造它的原因。” The state has the supra-human advantages of durability and reliability, and serves as a means of coördination.

;

;Runciman continues, “The Leviathan is not a problem-solving machine, like a smartphone. It is a decision-making mechanism, like a set of dice. It might not give you the right answer—it will simply give you ;an; answer.” In theory, these answers reflect the will of the polity. “But because it comprises people,” he writes, “once the people get better at coming up with answers, the state should too. These dice can think for themselves.” In practice, however, Hobbes is generally regarded as a pessimist. Of the Leviathan, Runciman writes: “Its argument assumes that humans are incapable of peaceful co-existence without franchising out our decision-making power to an unaccountable higher body. At that point, we will have lost control of our fate, because whatever the state decides becomes our choice too.” In Hobbes's time—of the well-known “war of all against all”—these powers were arbitrary and absolute, but this was the price to be paid for security. Runciman readily concedes that we have spent the past few hundred years constructing better mechanisms for democratic accountability, but “the basic machinery of the modern state continues to bear the hallmark of a mechanistic understanding of politics set out nearly four centuries ago. We still have governments that take decisions for us on matters of life and death, including war and peace.” He continues,

;
;
;

;We are bound by those decisions whether we like them or not. The state has the power to enforce its choices against anyone who resists, though it may not choose to use it. Most of the time, in contemporary democracies, these arbitrary powers are sufficiently buried beneath layers of legal limitations and political pushback that we barely notice them. But sometimes, in a crisis, they reveal themselves. Then we must acknowledge that we are still living with the Leviathan—older, wiser, but recognisably the same as before.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Without belaboring the comparison, Runciman elaborates a case for the state, which binds human reason in a lattice of rules and procedures, as an algorithmic device. The twinned essential functions of the state—the ability to issue debt and the prerogative of war—have undergirded its durability and afforded it a capacity for long-term planning that has thus far eluded other forms of human organization. For those of us privileged enough to escape the brutality of the state in the service of imperialist extraction, the state has considerably enhanced our longevity, wealth, and happiness. But the state, even if it comprises the human, is not itself human. “Our ability to fulfil our potential—to live longer, richer, more varied lives—was made possible only by handing over some of our capabilities to artificial versions of ourselves, which do not suffer from our natural frailties. We have had to give up features of our essential humanity—some of what Arendt would call our capacity for independent action—to enjoy these other benefits,” Runciman writes.

;
;
;

;So it should come as no surprise that the state cannot be counted upon to demonstrate a commitment to human values.它有自己的人造生命，即使它通过我们发挥作用——当我们被要求在战时杀人时，我们就被允许脱离人类价值观。朗西曼指出，国家是“毫无顾忌的人”，我们已经有数百年的时间来熟悉这种设计及其不满。从某种意义上说，机器学习时代只是机械时代的延伸。 “Let's not kid ourselves that the age of AI—with the looming challenges of black-box decision-making and algorithmic procedures whose outcomes are a mystery even to their creators—poses a unique challenge for human understanding.只要看看你自己的生活。你是否完全了解群体决策是如何决定你的身份的？”朗西曼写道。 “The fact that groups are made out of people doesn't make them any easier to see inside than other kinds of machines.黑匣子已经在我们周围了。 In one sense, at least, they ;are; us.”

;
;
;

;One of the things that make the machine of the capitalist state work is that some of its powers have been devolved upon other artificial agents—corporations. Where Runciman compares the state to a general AI, one that exists to serve a variety of functions, corporations have been granted a limited range of autonomy in the form of what might be compared to a narrow AI, one that exists to fulfill particular purposes that remain beyond the remit or the interests of the sovereign body. Corporations can thus be set up in free pursuit of a variety of idiosyncratic human enterprises, but they, too, are robotic insofar as they transcend the constraints and the priorities of their human members. The failure mode of governments is to become “exploitative and corrupt,” Runciman notes. The failure mode of corporations, as extensions of an independent civil society, is that “their independence undoes social stability by allowing those making the money to make their own rules.” There is only a “;narrow corridor;”—a term Runciman borrows from the economists Daron Acemoglu and James A. Robinson—in which the artificial agents balance each other out, and citizens get to enjoy the sense of control that emerges from an atmosphere of freedom and security. The ideal scenario is, in other words, a kludgy equilibrium.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Yet we citizens of modern states have always labored under the shadow of a partly mitigated alignment problem—a “mismatch between the drives of these artificial persons and the needs of the planet,” as Runciman describes it—that provides a frame, a vocabulary, and a sense of foreboding as we seek to process the automation on the horizon. The concern about unaligned machines is that even if we can program, so to speak, their ultimate ends, we can't necessarily anticipate the instrumental subgoals they might pursue as an intermediate measure.如果你指示一台机器完成一项任务，最可能的工具性子目标就是“获得控制权”。 If the danger of the alignment problem seems indistinct or preposterous, Runciman suggests, ;you haven't been paying attention;.

;

;So far, so continuous.在这一点上，诉诸先例应该会让人放心：鉴于这种被认为是新奇的痛苦来源事实证明与习惯性担忧相似，我们可以对人类生存和繁荣的能力充满信心——或者至少不是彻底沮丧。 Except Runciman doesn't do that.相反，他颠覆了标准的论证形式。 It's not that we can look to the past to help us solve the alignment problems of the future. It's that the alignment problems of the future help clarify our existing sense that everything is intractable and wrong. As Runciman puts it,

;
;
;

;States and corporations reflect two different sides of our contemporary fear of machines that have escaped human control. One is that we will build machines that we don't know how to switch off, either because we have become too dependent on them or because we can't find the off switch. That's states.另一个是我们建造的机器能够以我们无法再监管的方式进行自我复制。他们开始吐出我们自己的版本，直到我们被他们淹没。 That's corporations.

;
;
;

;Runciman quite clearly believes two things.首先，我们与强大机器的怨恨关系是有先例的。这似乎是个好消息。第二，承认这一先例并不能得出这样的结论：我们与强大机器的关系可以永远保持愉快。这可不是什么好消息。我们不仅未能解决国家或企业的原始结盟问题，而且事实上，随着时间的推移，情况变得更加严重。国家机器越来越远离普通公民的关注和价值观，权力的天平也向更强大的公司倾斜。人类价值观对于我们当前的官僚机构来说似乎和对于超然的神话超级智能一样重要。只要看看我们的行政管理失灵就知道了。 It's all well and good to call for more democracy, but greater participation in a system that's fundamentally out of whack won't get us far.

;

;And although Runciman's plummy tone never rises to the level of alarm, his prediction is that everything is about to get worse, and this is the point in his account where AI becomes more than a useful retrospective metaphor.如果我们最紧迫的关注是人类与机器之间的和平共处，那将是一回事。 But the more relevant prospect for unease is the rapport between machines and machines—between the automata of the state and the corporation and their AI kin. Some of the potential consequences are obvious: in the use of automated weaponry, for example, or comprehensive state surveillance of the kind that China, which has directed an enormous amount of resources into AI development, is pioneering.即使没有真正的人工超级智能，我们也可能会发现自己所困扰的不是单一的对齐问题，而是多个重叠的问题。 One of Runciman's few prescriptions is that we keep foremost in mind the distinction between a machine that gives us answers and a machine that makes decisions—that we might be OK if we grant machines the status of oracles rather than overlords. This proposition discounts the possibilities that AIs can learn to deceive. (There's evidence that they already have.) But, even if we can somehow make the machines promise they'll be honest, the line between an answer and a decision is blurry, and the path from the former to the latter short.冷战时期有一些著名的故事，讲述了军事下属拒绝发起核交锋的机会，但目前还不清楚他们将如何抵御依靠机器顾问运作的国家的力量。在审视了几种不同的存在风险的科幻场景后，朗西曼得出的结论是：“迄今为止，更大的风险似乎既不是流氓个人，也不是流氓技术，也不是流氓猴子，而是人造人出了问题。” The combination of the artificial agency of the state with even weak forms of artificial intelligence might be just as catastrophic as the regime of a single strong AI Plenty of people have issued similar warnings before. But those have often described a plot wherein a maniacal dictator wields a loosened AI Runciman's point is that the alliance between even a democratic government and a safe-ish AI could derail civilization.

;
;
;
;
;
;

;One can, of course, object to the dark story Runciman tells. Corporations have changed over time. As a consequence of the shareholder revolution, they have become more single-minded in their pursuit of profit maximization, but one doesn't have to look back very far to find examples of corporate structures that optimized for more variables than just the bottom line. In a recent podcast episode devoted to the book, the political theorist Lea Ypi reminded Runciman that our current political and corporate configurations hardly exhaust the possibilities for collective life. The point of a book like David Graeber and David Wengrow's “;The Dawn of Everything;,” to which Runciman delivers a rebuttal in a lengthy footnote, is that the state as machine is a historical contingency rather than an inevitable by-product of coördinated action at scale.

;

;Is that beside the point?很难说。 States might be much more than the sum of their human parts, but they're supposed to derive their legitimacy from the popular will, which means that as artificial “persons without scruples” they are nonetheless vulnerable to our appeals. They are run by people who at least in theory can be communicated with. The fact that this hasn't often been achieved doesn't mean that such an achievement is forever out of reach. The problem with an unaligned AI is that it won't care much about people one way or the other, and will remain impervious to our cries for consideration. Runciman devotes a perfunctory concluding chapter to scenarios like these, but it doesn't seem to rank highly among his priorities. This isn't because he's ruled out the likelihood of an AI doomsday, but because he considers it a failure of imagination. Members of the AI-safety community, he writes, are so taken with their own prophecies that they fail to consider how thoroughly we've already compromised our decision-making: “They overestimate the worth of human intelligence, and as a result they underestimate what stands in its way.” For Runciman, we'll be lucky if we can coax into alignment the machines we've made of ourselves, never mind the ones made of silicon. ♦

;Americans are so used to seeing history played by Americans that the oddity of it hardly registers anymore.查尔顿·赫斯顿是西班牙人的熙德、希伯来人、埃及人的摩西和犹太人的宾虚——不管你信不信，他因此获得了奥斯卡奖——无论他扮演谁，无论这个角色应该在哪里，他的中西部口音都被认为是理所当然的。 have lived.

;

;And why not?没有人指望《凯撒大帝》中的演员能说一口流利的拉丁语。小说是所有小说的前提，这个简单的事实，以及（也许正在衰落的）伴随的事实，即大多数电影明星都是在美国诞生的，足以解释这一现象。 Indeed, the whole point and rationale—the raison d'être, as we say in English—of the theatrical arts is to extend our circles of compassion through acts of creative empathy: we ;want; people who are unlike the characters they play to inhabit them so that in acts of sympathetic resonance we too expand ourselves. It's why we love Laurence Olivier's Shylock, or, for that matter, Russell Crowe's gladiator.

;

;Yet, when one has something, if no more than a big toe, resting in another culture, the oddity resonates. Though Joaquin Phoenix plays Napoleon, for the most part ably, in ;Ridley Scott;'s much talked-of ;new movie; of the Emperor's life and battles, it's still disconcerting that he says his lines not only in English but more or less with exactly the same accents—and using exactly the same slightly paralyzed set of expressions—with which he ;inhabited; Johnny Cash.他的角色的演员阵容仍然是他的角色的演员阵容，菲尼克斯以经典的电影明星方式进行了调整，但角色之间没有显着的差异； he is no Lon Chaney, nor nearly an Olivier, inventing a new face and voice for each role.

;

;This oddity has not been missed in the French reception to the film.几乎所有法国评论家都用斜体字来描述拿破仑历史角色的模糊性——他是亚历山大大帝的转世还是希特勒的邪恶前身？ Perhaps the sole exception is the far-right polemicist and onetime Presidential candidate ;Éric Zemmour;, who contributed a laudatory story to the far-right magazine ;Valeurs actuelles; with the cover line “L'empereur anti-woke ”。不管多么不可思议，“觉醒”已经成为法国争论中无处不在的借用词，尤其是在反美极右翼分子中。你可能会认为那些相信美国正在殖民法国文化的人会找到一个法语单词来表达他们的蔑视，但他们没有。他们轻蔑地使用美国这个词，但他们确实这么做了。 It's as if, in anti-French polemics, we insisted on condemning their undue ;sang-froid;. Apparently, no one has stopped to consider the power of a culture that forced you to borrow its language to condemn it.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;But most of the arguments against “Napoleon” were about language in another way, and more nettled. “这部电影并没有因为这两个人的事实而感到困扰。 。 。 warring factions speak the same language (English), which never ceases to feel odd,” a film critic at ;Le Monde; ;wrote;. “Directed by a Briton who has long reigned over Hollywood, ;Napoleon; is a film that essentially reminds us that the Empire has changed hands since Waterloo.” （用这个略显精妙的公式，批评者的意思是好莱坞像法国人一样统治着世界。） 当然，人们只能想象美国人看到一部关于亚伯拉罕·林肯的生活的极其昂贵和精心制作的电影会有什么感觉。 Gérard Depardieu in the lead, and with wartime Washington perfectly realized and Gettysburg thrillingly re-created, but with everyone from bedroom to battlefield muttering and roaring in guttural French and using idiomatic French expressions to summon up the American ones—“;Ah, alors!;,” “;Sacré bleu;,” “;Monsieur le President;,” and so on.这样的电影将传达“拿破仑”在法语母语人士中引发的超现实文化错位，更不用说意想不到的喜剧了。这与其说是一个棘手的文化挪用问题，不如说是一个更直接的喜剧不协调问题。 Though languages do not, in truth, ;enclose singular domains of meaning;, there are still patterns of behavior, ways of addressing the world, acculturated norms of discourse and style, that affect all members of a linguistic practice.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;To take one subtle and circular example, the French aristocrats in “Napoleon” are played mostly by English actors affecting upper-crust English accents that rather betray the equivalent speech pattern in French, which is not clipped and reserved but sonorous and rhetorically sinuous. (The foreign minister Charles-Maurice de Talleyrand would not hesitate to orate at his emperor, rather than interrogate him politely, as he does here.) That rhetorical tone of French conversation—still dominant now, and overwhelming in the ;very; rhetorical early nineteenth century—is dislodged by the clipped manner of those Brits, not to mention the Method-y pauses and mumblings with which Phoenix works, in a style that is eerily Brando-esque. (Who also once undertook to play Napoleon.)

;
;
;

;But this means that, when an actual British upper-cruster, in this case the Duke of Wellington, played by Rupert Everett, appears, he has to go ;way; over the top in order to distinguish himself from the clipped Brits playing the French.他必须成为英国上流社会的一种令人愤慨的讽刺，全是哼哼和冷笑，这样（这是圆形的部分）他最终的表现就像法国人传统上讽刺的马脸和毫无幽默感的英国人一样，就像, for instance, the Astérix comics.

;
;
;

;It's the fiendishly hidden English prejudices of the movie, though, that the French find most pernicious. “This film was made by an Englishman” was the historian Patrice Gueniffey's blunt ;verdict; in the magazine ;Le Point;, “and openly anti-French.” (Gueniffey has written two mostly ;admiring; ;books; about the Emperor.) The many historical anomalies in the movie—which are bound to be there—are viewed with his suspicious eye as part of a pattern of anti-French sentiment.拿破仑并没有像电影开头那样接近处决玛丽·安托瓦内特，这使得拿破仑的威权主义似乎是对恐怖统治的反应，只有在非常普遍的意义上才是正确的：希特勒的崛起与之前的魏玛通货膨胀有关——这个序列中有许多缺失的步骤。 But this is, as in both Edmund Burke and “A Tale of Two Cities,” the traditional British way of imagining the revolution: the bloody-minded French need a boss, or they go mad.

;

;Napoleon's expedition to Egypt, meanwhile, is represented as a kind of creepy mix of loot-taking and pyramid-destroying, though in fact Bonaparte and his men never aimed cannons at the peaks of pyramids, as they do here, and the expedition came complete with an earnest set of scholars, including the great Vivant Denon, and led eventually to Champollion's decipherment of Egyptian hieroglyphics. The Rosetta stone, taken from Egypt by Napoleon, was in turn taken from him by the Brits—it still lives in the British Museum—and so Napoleon's sagacious purpose in Egypt is presumably deliberately left out of the “British” movie.

;

;Worse still, from the French view, the Emperor is portrayed as a clumsy lover. One of the current Bonapartist pretenders—there are two, with different lineage—the Prince Murat, a descendant of Napoleon's brother-in-law, was so offended by this that he was moved to write indignantly in ;Le Figaro; on behalf of the Emperor's erotic equipoise. （有两个拿破仑与约瑟芬发生性关系的难看的场景，拿破仑衣着整齐，从后面做爱。）王子抗议说，皇帝的做爱“像一个笨拙、笨拙和受惊的小男孩”，但随后他补充道，难怪，因为他自始至终都被描绘成“笨拙、幼稚、残忍、优柔寡断和软弱”。 (The pretender still recommended the film, seemingly on the ground that getting people thinking Bonaparte is always a good idea.)

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Yet what truly offends French opinion about the film is a very French thing: the failure to sufficiently dramatize administrative excellence.拿破仑是一个平庸的将军，但却是一位出色的国家管理者，这是一个合理的违反直觉的例子——他输掉了关键战役，并做出了注定要失败的决定，试图从海路入侵英国，然后从陆路入侵俄罗斯，但他催生的民法典仍然存在今天，他的任人唯贤、“向人才开放”的职业理念确实是新颖且持久的。影片没有明确说明的一件事是，拿破仑身边的人已经从军中晋升，而他的将军和元帅则像很可能是科西嘉岛的痞子作为波旁贵族。 Napoleon was a hands-on manager and promoter of men—he once even wrote sympathetically about a lowly corporal with a drinking problem.

;

;Gueniffey also insists that the casualty numbers that run in the credits at the end of “Napoleon,” intended to make one aware of the horror inflicted by the man whom the film has just spent the past two and a half hours heroizing, are greatly inflated.无论如何，两个拿破仑——复活的亚历山大还是早产的希特勒——之间的永久选择不会在这里解决。在阿贝尔·冈斯传奇的五个半小时无声版本中扮演波拿巴的演员阿尔伯特·迪厄多内 (Albert Dieudonné) 穿着拿破仑服装下葬。 Phoenix seems likelier to go to his grave as Johnny Cash.

;

;Still, the cult of the Emperor won't end, and even an often awkward film can't end it.在几个场景中，拿破仑在扮演皇帝的同时也被艺术家描绘，这部分是真实的：魅力十足的暴君吸引了当时更优秀的艺术家。大卫、席里科和安格尔都是他的直接追随者——这是当代独裁者无法比拟的，尽管也许只是因为周围有更好的艺术家阶层。毕竟，拿破仑能够愚弄许多天才，让他们认为他可能是共和理想的实现者，就像贝多芬和为拿破仑写的《英雄英雄》一样，直到贝多芬弄清楚他到底是谁。 (“Now, too, he will tread under foot all the rights of Man, indulge only his ambition; now he will think himself superior to all men, become a tyrant!”)

;

;When Napoleon fell and the French painters sighed and went to work for the mediocre royals who followed him, they did not do good work—until Delacroix's “Liberty Leading the People,” made for the revolution of 1830, restored the nobility of revolutionary painting, which retains its own peculiar and glamorous aura to this day.但是，革命的浪漫荣耀也许是这个时代及其皇帝留给我们的最独特的文化口音。它解释了为什么拿破仑电影从来没有拍得好，也永远不会停止制作，无论用什么语言。 ♦

;One of the most graceful experiences I've had at the movies this year is the last part of “Monster,” the drama directed by Hirokazu Kore-eda that's currently in theatres, but it takes a saintly patience to sit through the hour-plus of action that precedes it. 《怪物》是腼腆而谨慎的，它的故事由三个部分组成，叙事界限清晰。每部电影都以故事中的不同角色为中心，但这并不是一部含糊不清的电影；这是消除歧义并暴露偏见的一种方式。读者请注意：考虑到是枝裕和所使用的戏剧性转折，就好像它们是针对观众道德缺陷的缓释药物一样，对这部电影的任何明智的讨论都无法完全避免剧透。然而这些支点并不重要。 What matters in “Monster” isn't the gamesmanship built into its structure but the imaginative richness, the emotional immediacy, and the vital performances that are concentrated in its extended third section.

;

;The first part follows a widow named Saori (Sakura Ando), whose son, Minato (Soya Kurokawa), a fifth grader, complains of being insulted and even physically abused by his homeroom teacher, Mr. Hori (Eita Nagayama).第二部分描述了相同的事件，这次集中于堀对这些事件的看法。第三部分以凑本人为中心，消除了前两部分的神秘面纱，从而揭示了成年角色的狭隘误判，因为他们没有从了解完整的故事中获益。 It also overturns misunderstandings that viewers will have formed, led on by the earlier sections' calculated red herrings.

;

;The movie, written by Yûji Sakamoto, is set in a small provincial city.市中心的一栋高层建筑着火，成为人们议论的话题。沙织工作的干洗店的一位顾客向她提到，该干洗店的一层设有一家女主人酒吧，据说堀织经常光顾这家酒吧，这对老师来说是不恰当的行为。与此同时，她的儿子凑显然很烦恼，并告诉她堀拉了他的耳朵，流了他的鼻子，并称他是一个长着猪脑的怪物。当沙织去学校投诉时，她遭到了恭敬礼貌的阻挠——回避和偏颇、含糊其辞的道歉和厚颜无耻的谎言。 The discussion gets heated, and Hori accuses Minato of bullying another boy in the class named Yori (Hinata Hiiragi).

;
;
;

;In the second part, laying out Hori's romantic life, his sense of persecution by Minato's mother, and his humiliation over the accusations, Kore-eda tweaks the drama to signal more clearly endemic social ills: the stifling of free expression by an elaborate code of proprieties;基于自我克制价值的狭隘行政规则强制执行沉默规范的方式；其他传统形式的父权制、大男子主义压迫的加剧。起诉书是有力的，但如果它以更广泛的范围和更细粒度的行动更巧妙地引发——或者更坦率地、带有强烈的谴责性，那么它就会更有力。 Instead, the film lands somewhere in between, with a feeling of one-to-one correspondence in the way that a given action or utterance pins a given idea to the screen, allowing no nonconforming excess of observation or of emotion.

;

;The problem with information being dosed out like this goes beyond a viewer's uneasy feeling of being toyed with by a filmmaker.这种策略实际上也影响了电影制片人，强加了一种狭隘的视野，一种缩小视角和想象力的戏剧性目的论。在电影的第一部分中，沙织对港区日益增长的麻烦感提供了一股强大的叙事能量暗流，但是枝裕和被迫将其浪费掉。为了避免过早透露太多信息，他删去了母子讨论的场景，同样，也删去了沙织与堀和其他学校官员的对抗场景。这些对抗的言语攻击和招架都是精心设计的，表演也经过精心校准。安藤在调节沙织不断增长的愤怒的方式中存在着一种微妙的热情，而田中优子作为一名怀有自己的耻辱的学校校长，传达了潜藏在冷静僵化的形式背后的紧张气氛。然而一次又一次，当这些场景达到紧张的关键时刻时，它们就结束了。在观看过程中，我最常对自己说的话就是对被悬吊着感到困惑；毕竟，角色如何摆脱戏剧性的僵局或潜在的灾难与他们如何陷入困境同样重要。 Instead, Kore-eda cuts and cuts to fit the Procrustean demands of his scheme.

;

;The revelations of the third section, retroactively clarifying the story, turn out to be far more than mere plot points.影片中以水门与赖的友谊为中心的这一部分，显然是是枝裕和编剧坂本深深投入的一部，是他们用心填满、想象力和好奇心终于得以自由发挥的一部。港区很难公开承认这是一种友谊，因为尤里——身材娇小、调皮、声音高亢——是欺凌的目标。水门害怕与他有联系，尽管他采取了异常而鲁莽的措施来保护他。两个男孩一起玩着奇妙而欢乐的幻想游戏。 There are intensely dramatic moments reminiscent of some of the most agonizing scenes in “;Moonlight;,” including a sublime fillip of revolt against oppressive paternal authority.在港区的另一个场景中，尤里以孩子般的方式思考宇宙的终结和时间的本质，涉及食物、粪便和他们自己的诞生；是枝裕和和坂本对聪明孩子的思辨气质和强大的记忆力表现出冷静而惊人的敏感度，而柊则创造了近期儿童演员表演中最精致的时刻之一。到目前为止，写作是如此细致，如此多样，方向如此专注，表演如此富有同情心，以至于第三部分本身几乎就像一部电影，比整个电影有更深层次和更丰富的体验。它适合。 ♦

;The American public's increasing fascination with artificial intelligence—its rapid advancement and ability to reshape the future—has put the computer scientist Geoffrey Hinton in an awkward position.他被称为人工智能教父，因为他在神经网络方面的开创性工作，这是大多数研究人员放弃的计算机科学的一个分支，而辛顿的进步最终引发了一场革命。但他现在担心这可能会带来什么后果。 “我和其他人都担心很多风险。 。 。 。 I'm a kind of latecomer to worrying about the risks, ” Hinton tells ;The New Yorker's; Joshua Rothman. “因为最近我得出的结论是，这些数字智能可能已经和我们一样优秀了。他们能够比我们更好地相互交流知识。” Hinton 对技术的了解让他觉得目前不可能限制人工智能的意图和目标，因为人工智能不可避免地会变得比人类更聪明。他仍然是一名研究员，不再在人工智能的成功中拥有经济利益，因此他可能比萨姆·奥尔特曼和其他科技大亨更坦率地看待人工智能革命的缺点。他同意，外行人希望人工智能消失“并非没有道理”，“但这不会发生。 。 。 。它非常有用，有很多做好事的机会。”我们应该做什么？罗斯曼问他。 “我不知道。 Smart young people,” Hinton hopes, “should be thinking about, is it possible to prevent [AI] from ever wanting to take over.”

;;Days 1-5: Menstruation;
